raw_text:
Junk e-mails on relentless rise
 
 Spam traffic is up by 40%, putting the total amount of e-mail that is junk up to an astonishing 90%.
 
 The figures, from e-mail management firm Email Systems, will alarm firms attempting to cope with the amount of spam in their in-boxes. While virus traffic has slowed down, denial of service attacks are on the increase according to the firm. Virus mail accounts for just over 15% of all e-mail traffic analysis by the firm has found.
 
 It is no longer just multi-nationals that are in danger of so-called denial of service attacks, in which websites are bombarded by requests for information and rendered inaccessible. Email Systems refers to a small UK-based engineering firm, which received a staggering 12 million e-mails in January. The type of spam currently being sent has subtlety altered in the last few months, according to Email Systems analysis. Half of spam received since Christmas has been health-related with gambling and porn also on the increase. Scam mails, offering ways to make a quick buck, have declined by 40%. "January is clearly a month when consumers are less motivated to purchase financial products or put money into dubious financial opportunities," said Neil Hammerton, managing director of Email Systems. "Spammers seem to have adapted their output to reflect this, focussing instead on medically motivated and pornographic offers, presumably intentionally intended to coincide with what is traditionally considered to be the bleakest month in the calendar," he said.
llama3.2:1b: Junk e-mails are up 40% and total junk emails now at 90%, according to email management firm Email Systems.
Spam accounts for 15% of all e-mail traffic, and denial-of-service attacks on websites have increased.
The type of spam sent has shifted to more health-related and scam-related messages, such as gambling and porn offerings.
llama3.2:3b: Spam email traffic has increased by 40% to a total of 90%, with virus mail accounting for 15%.
A UK-based engineering firm received 12 million spam emails in January, while scam mails have declined.
Health-related spam, gambling, and porn are on the rise, with spammers adapting their content to coincide with traditionally bleak months like January.

Virus mail represents just over 15% of total traffic.

Denial of service attacks are also common, with a significant proportion (15%) of all e-mails analyzed by Email Systems having been attacked recently.
Half of the emails received since Christmas are health-related and gambling scams have declined.

Spam content has shifted towards health-related and pornographic offers since Christmas.
Scam mails have decreased by 40%, coinciding with the traditionally less active month for financial transactions.
opencoder:1.5b: The rise of junk e-mails has led to an increase in spam traffic.
This has spurred a surge in total junk emails as 90% of this increase comes from the rise of denial-of-service attacks, with virus mail accounts for approximately 15% of all email traffic analysis.
Email systems have identified that there is a significant shift in the types of spam being sent and its frequency since Christmas.
Half of spam received since Christmas has been health-related with gambling and porn also on the increase.
Several companies, like Email Systems, have reported declines due to these advancements in the form of scams offering ways to make quick buck and make fraudulent financial deals.
The company said it expects to see a greater adaptation of its output based on this analysis.

The figures from email management firm Email Systems indicate that the number of spam emails is increasing and virus traffic is slowing down.
However, denial of service attacks are on the rise as well according to the firm.
Virus mail accounts for just over 15% of all e-mail traffic analyzed by the firm has found.
It is no longer just multi-nationals that are in danger of so-called denial of service attacks, in which websites are bombarded by requests for information and rendered inaccessible.
Email Systems refers to a small UK-based engineering firm, which received a staggering 12 million e-mails in January.
The type of spam currently being sent has subtlety altered in the last few months, according to Email Systems analysis.
Half of spam received since Christmas has been health-related with gambling and porn also on the increase.
Scam mails, offering ways to make a quick buck, have declined by 40%.

"January is clearly a month when consumers are less motivated to purchase financial products or put money into dubious financial opportunities," said Neil Hammerton, managing director of Email Systems.

"Spammers seem to have adapted their output to reflect this, focussing instead on medically motivated and pornographic offers, presumably intentionally intended to coincide with what is traditionally considered to be the bleakest month in the calendar."

In January, they received 12 million emails, with health-related and gambling content rising.

Scams declined by 40%, while manager Neil Hammerton notes consumers are less motivated during non-qualifying months, amid spammers adapting their strategies for medical or porn-related offers coinciding with traditionally bleakest months.

The type of spam is also changing, with a shift towards medically motivated and pornographic offers during January, when consumers are less motivated to purchase financial products or put money into dubious opportunities.

These spam messages, which can be as innocuous or malicious as one might imagine, account for nearly half of all the emails received by the company last month.
The figures from Email Systems suggest that denial-of-service attacks have also been on the rise, with 15% of email traffic viewed by the firm being viewed inaccessible to users.

Since Christmas, health-related spam and pornography have increased while scam mail offers have decreased by 40%.
The author believes spammers are adapting their output to reflect consumer behavior during the bleakest month of the year.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Spam email traffic has surged by 40%, now constituting 90% of all emails, as reported by Email Systems.
Despite a decrease in virus mail (15%), denial-of-service attacks are escalating.
A notable UK engineering firm received 12 million spam emails in January alone.
Recent trends reveal a shift in spam content: health and gambling-related offers have risen by half since Christmas, while scam mails promising quick profits have decreased by 40%.
This shift may reflect reduced consumer interest in financial schemes during typically gloomy months, according to Email Systems' managing director Neil Hammerton.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Spam e-mail traffic has risen by 40%, now making up 90% of all e-mails, according to Email Systems.
While virus-related e-mails have decreased, denial of service attacks are increasing, affecting not just large corporations but also small businesses.
A UK engineering firm received 12 million e-mails in January alone.
Recent spam trends show a shift towards health-related, gambling, and pornographic content, while scam e-mails have declined by 40%.
Spammers appear to be adjusting their tactics based on consumer behavior, targeting medical and adult content during traditionally low financial activity periods.
